review.title: Quantum Consciousness Soccer Simulator
review.abstract: In cognitive sciences it is not uncommon to use various games effectively. For example, in artificial intelligence, the RoboCup initiative was to set up to catalyse research on the field of autonomous agent technology. In this paper, we introduce a similar soccer simulation initiative to try to investigate a model of human consciousness and a notion of reality in the form of a cognitive problem. In addition, for example, the home pitch advantage and the objective role of the supporters could be naturally described and discussed in terms of this new soccer simulation model.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The robot football, or generally referred to as RoboCup, is a standard problem for catalyst research in the field of autonomous agent technology [14]. In RoboCup there are several different types of leagues. Currently, in the case of RoboCup 2D Soccer Simulation League (2D RCSS), all aspects of the game of the best teams in the world are fairly real when compared with games between different humanoid teams, while the same does not apply to the case of the other leagues of RoboCup. In 2D football simulations, the rcssserver [19] establishes the reality of the simulated football world. Through UDP / IP, client agents have connected with this simulated reality.

sections.heading: 3 The First Reference Implementations
sections.text: In the case of RoboCup, there are only players and coaches. In contrast, football fans also need to be treated in the newly introduced simulation environment. There is the main difficulty of implementation, as the number of followers can exceed 80,000. This is only partially a technical problem, as it also raises questions of principle regarding the heterogeneous composition of the followers. In terms of the technical problem, it may be a possibility to use CUDA [16] GPU, where device threads would correspond to the followers. To deal with heterogeneity, we can create different archetypes such as attackers, midfielders and defenders among the players. It should be noted that similar difficulties will arise in dealing with couch potato fans, as their number may reach hundreds of thousands. In this case, a Java-EE-based [13] solution could be explored.In this chapter, we will focus only on such an implementation, which will examine the development of the basics of the football game.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Further Work
sections.text: During implementation, there may be the introduction of new roles such as ball or pitch, where the members of these new roles might know, for example, the motion equations of the Newton. However, it would be a mistake because, for example, the laws of motion would arise by themselves. At this moment, the agents included in the experimental implementation cannot play football. This implementation may only be used to test the performance and timing of the architecture. The next step is to program player and fan agents to play football. For example, the simplified algorithms of the FerSML platform can be used for the (subjective) implementation of the movement of players and their passports. With minimal customization, the FerSML platform can also be used to visualize the stream of the selected state vectors as a football game.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: It is undeniable that this essay has focused directly on football, but in fact it suggests much more than just football. This is an initiative to create a community of programmers who want to help develop successful QCSS-based football teams and QCSS-based football fan groups. We hope and believe that our new simulation concept can provide an exciting framework for studying concrete models for establishing reality and that it could become a standard cognitive problem, as RoboCup has become in the field of AI over the last 15 years. However, in order to return to football, the objective role of fans in the proposed new simulation model becomes apparent, and this objective role could explain the home advantage, because in the case of a home game it means that many home fans can watch the game in the home team stadium. Thus, the direct reason for the home advantage is simply the impact of the objective role of home fans.
